dc:description:
*LRP12* encodes low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 12, which is involved in signal transduction and endocytosis. *LRP12* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant oculopharyngodistal myopathy (OPDM; OMIM: 164310) in 2019 (Ishiura et al., PMID: 31332380). OPDM, due to CGG expansions in *LRP12*, is characterized by the adult-onset ptosis (eyelid droop), external ophthalmoplegia (eye muscle weakness), facial muscle weakness, distal limb muscle weakness and atrophy, dysphagia, and dysarthria. Skeletal muscle biopsy reveals myopathic changes with rimmed vacuoles. The trinucleotide expansions in *LRP12* are also reported to cause autosomal dominant amyotrophic lateral sclerosis 28 (ALS 28; OMIM: 620452). It is proposed that the size of the expansion may impact disease presentation. Full expansion of the CGG repeat (>100) is thought to cause OPDM, while an intermediate expansion (~60-100, although lower limit is not yet well-defined) has been associated with ALS 28. Furthermore, a co-existence of individuals with OPDM and ALS 28 carrying >100 CGG repeats and 60-100 CGG repeats, respectively, in *LRP12* has been observed within a single family (Kim et al., 2023, PMID: 37339631). Given the overlap in genetic variation and lack of replication defining the number of repeats differentiating an intermediate expansion from a full expansion, following assessment of the criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, the ALS GCEP determined that ALS 28 would be lumped with OPDM. 

No case-control analyses were reported for the curation of *LRP12*; however, one family with individuals presenting with OPDM or ALS 28 dependent on CGG repeat expansion length was scorable with four segregations and a calculated LOD score of 1.2 (Kume et al., 2023, PMID: 37339631). The same publication was the only report from which case-level evidence was obtained specifically for *LRP12*’s relationship with ALS 28, with 1.6 points of genetic evidence based on the identification of expansions ranging from 61-95 repeats in length in five probands, four of which were considered to have functional evidence. Additionally, 66 probands with OPDM carrying repeat expansions >100 repeats in length were scored, reported across six publications (PMIDs: 31332380, 32493488, 33374016, 34047774, 34466670, 36052448). Based on the curation, a genetic evidence score of 8.1 was reached. The gene-disease association is not supported by additional experimental evidence, resulting in an experimental evidence score of zero.

In summary, there is moderate evidence to support the gene-disease relationship of *LRP12* with ALS 28 and OPDM. More evidence is needed to establish *LRP12*’s relationship with ALS 28, including genetic evidence and experimental evidence to determine the molecular mechanism of the pathogenic repeats and definitively identify the number of repeats defining intermediate and full expansions. No convincing contradictory evidence has emerged for the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen ALS GCEP on May 14, 2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: Likely not de novo as there is a family history of ALS. The other functional evidence presented was specific to the other individual carriers, so was not considered for this proband. Proband carried repeat lengths of 61/11
Proband was found to have a CGG repeat length of 70/13.

Immunofluorescent analysis revealed LRP12-positive intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions in the iPSMNs of individuals with LRP12-ALS and OPDM. iPSMNs from HCs showed LRP12-positive inclusions in the cytoplasm but not in the nuclei (Figure 3A). In addition, iPSMNs from LRP12-ALS-affected individuals had cytoplasmic granules positive for pTDP-43 (Figure 3B). These granules did not appear skein like or round but were similar to the mislocalized inclusions seen in iPSCs derived from ALS-affected individuals in a previous report. iPSMNs from LRP12-OPDM-affected individuals and HCs did not contain pTDP-43-positive cytoplasmic granules (Figures 3B and S6A). RNA-FISH revealed nuclear RNA accumulations in iPSMNs from both LRP12-ALS-affected and LRP12-OPDM-affectged individuals but not HCs (Figure 3C). Paraffin-embedded iPSMN cell blocks showed intranuclear RNA accumulations in both LRP12-ALS-affected individuals and LRP12-OPDM-affected individuals. Cell blocks from HCs did not show nuclear RNA accumulations (Figures 3D). The iPSMNs of individuals with LRP12-ALS frequently showed nuclear RNA accumulations compared with those of individuals with LRP12-OPDM (p = 0.044) (Figures 3E). RNA-FISH showed nuclear RNA accumulations in the muscle biopsy specimens of both LRP12-ALS-affected and LRP12-OPDM-affected individuals but not HCs (Figures 4A).
Carried an unknown number of repeats
Two samples were assessed - one sample had a repeat length of 127, the other had a repeat length of 159
Assumed not de novo as father also had OPDM1. Exact number of repeats not provided, only expansion indicated

The size of the expansion was not give, although repeat primed PCR figures indicate that the expansion was >100 repeats. The expansion was also found in the sibling of the proband, who was also affected. An expansion was found in 4 other familial OPDM and 8 sporadic OPDM cases from this same group that had been histopathology confirmed. The authors had 54 other non-histopathology confirmed OPDM cases, in which 9 were also found to carry the expansion. No clinical details were provided for the other participants/carriers

The other functional evidence presented was specific to the other individual carriers, so was not considered for this proband. Proband carried repeat lengths of 86/9
ALS GCEP asked to upgrade this variant marginally, as the number of repeats was > the number of repeats for which the authors had shown functional evidence.
Had two samples sequenced, one carried 261 repeats, the other carried 284 repeats
Carried 530, 110, 1900 repeats depending on source of the DNA sample. Mother had 460 repeats and was also affected.
Carried an unknown number of repeats
Carried an unknown number of repeats
Had multiple samples assessed, one carried 177 repeats, the other carried 224 repeats
Carried 112 repeats, also had a brother with onset at 60 years old that carried 130 repeats

The other functional evidence presented was specific to the other individual carriers, so was not considered for this proband. Proband carried repeat lengths of 80/9
ALS GCEP asked to upgrade this variant marginally, as the number of repeats was > the number of repeats for which the authors had shown functional evidence.
Carried 128 repeats; also had a brother (Patient 28) with onset at 36yrs that carried 126 repeats
Carried an unknown number of repeats
Had two samples sequenced, one carried 162 repeats, the other carried 198 samples

Carried 144 repeats. Affected sibling carried 140 repeats.
Had multiple samples sequenced, one carried 165 repeats, the other carried 189 repeats

evidence.rdfs:label: Family F797 (Isiura et al. 2019)

member.rdfs:label: F7967: III-1 (Isiura et al. 2019)
member.detectionMethod: Performed whole-genome sequence analysis of patient III-1 of family F7967 and searched directly for CGG repeats. Repeat primed PCR confirmed the presence of the repeat and was used to assess all 33 other patients/families
member.phenotypeFreeText:
Biopsied muscle specimens confirmed the presence of myopathic changes with rimmed
vacuoles
member.previousTestingDescription: Negative for GCG repeat expansions in PABPN1 (the causative gene for oculopharyngeal muscular dystrophy (OPMD; MIM164300)31) and CGG repeat expansions in LOC642361/NUTM2B-AS1

evidence.phenotypeFreeText:
Biopsied muscle specimens confirmed the presence of myopathic changes with rimmed
vacuoles

evidence.rdfs:label: Family 4 (Kume et al. 2024)

member.rdfs:label: Family 4 III-3 (Kume et al. 2024)
member.detectionMethod: Fluorescence amplicon length analysis and repeat-primed PCR
member.phenotypeFreeText: Family members presented with progressive muscular atrophy variant of ALS. Proband presented with dysarthria and reduced reflex

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Family members presented with progressive muscular atrophy variant of ALS

member.rdfs:label: F11658: 5 (Shimizu et al 2022)
member.detectionMethod: Repeat-primed polymerase chain reaction (PCR) analysis targeting LRP12, LOC642361, GIPC1,and NOTCH2NLC was performed and Southern blot hybridization analysis was also done to determine the lengths of expanded repeats in LRP12
member.previousTestingDescription: OPMD was excluded in all10 of the patients based on the result of analysis of GCG/GCA repeatexpansions inPABPN1.

member.rdfs:label: Family 5 III-5 (Kume et al. 2024)
member.detectionMethod: Fluorescence amplicon length analysis and repeat-primed PCR
member.phenotypeFreeText: Diagnosed with progressive muscular atrophy variant of ALS

evidence.rdfs:label: OPDM1 Family (Saito et al. 2020)

member.rdfs:label: III-5 (Saito et al. 2020)
member.detectionMethod: Repeat-primed PCR was used to identify the CGG repeat.
member.phenotypeFreeText: Both the proband and his father developed adult-onset ptosis, distal-dominant slowly progressive myopathy with rimmed vacuoles (RVs), dysphagia, and external ophthalmoplegia. Ultrastructural analysis of the necropsied scalenus muscle revealed tubulofilamentous inclusions in the muscle fiber nuclei. A general autopsy of the proband unexpectedly revealed coexisting NIID histopathology. Almost all organs including the central and peripheral nervous systems, except for the skeletal muscles, showed abundant round, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions that were positive for ubiquitin (Fig. 3b) and p62 and most frequently detectable in the sympathetic and dorsal root ganglia.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Both the proband and his father developed adult-onset ptosis, distal-dominant slowly progressive myopathy with rimmed vacuoles (RVs), dysphagia, and external ophthalmoplegia. Ultrastructural analysis of the necropsied scalenus muscle revealed tubulofilamentous inclusions in the muscle fiber nuclei. A general autopsy of the proband unexpectedly revealed coexisting NIID histopathology. Almost all organs including the central and peripheral nervous systems, except for the skeletal muscles, showed abundant round, eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions that were positive for ubiquitin (Fig. 3b) and p62 and most frequently detectable in the sympathetic and dorsal root ganglia.

evidence.dc:description: Note that it is not explicitly stated that all regions within the linkage region were assessed using the long-read sequencing, but it is left to be assumed in the way it is written. The authors were quick comprehensive, completing exome, genome, and long read sequencing,
evidence.rdfs:label: Family 1 (Kume et al. 2024)

member.rdfs:label: Family 1 II-6 (Kume et al. 2024)
member.detectionMethod: To identify the causative variant, SNP genotyping was first performed. Linkage analysis using Allegro identified several regions with LOD scores of ∼2 (Figure S2B). Exome and genome sequencing were used in the affected individuals, but short read sequencing could not identify candidate variants. Long read sequencing was then performed on the affected individuals. Using tandem-genotypes, they identified CGG repeat expansions in the 5' UTR of LRP12 (Figure 1D), which was validated using repeat-primed PCR and fluorescence amplicon length analysis (Figure 1E)
member.phenotypeFreeText: Slowly progressing muscle weakness beginning in their 40s. In their 50s, they showed muscle weakness, and two had a positive jaw reflex. In their 60s, the individuals started to use wheelchairs.
member.previousTestingDescription: Although the authors indicate that SNP genotyping as well as exome and genome sequencing were performed on the affected and some unaffected family members, they only explicitly state that "candidate variants" could not be found with the whole exome and genome sequencing.

evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Slowly progressing muscle weakness beginning in their 40s. In their 50s, they showed muscle weakness, and two had a positive jaw reflex. In their 60s, the individuals started to use wheelchairs.

evidence.dc:description: Had two samples assessed, one carried 219 repeats, the other carried 289 repeats; also had two sisters that carried repeats: one with age of onset of 45 yrs and carried 85 repeats, and the other with age of onset of 30 years that carried 127 reepeats
Carried 195 repeats; had a brother with onset at 17 yrs that carried 208 repeats (Patient 51)
Had multiple samples sequenced, one carried 129 repeats, the other carried 158 repeats
